Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Lymphatic Venous Anastomosis for Preventing Cellulitis in Lower Extremity Lymphoedema

Trial_Design.evidence: Patients with secondary lower extremity lymphoedema who had undergone at least 3 months of non-operative decongestive therapy were randomly assigned

Participants.evidence: Patients with secondary lower extremity lymphoedema who had undergone at least 3 months of non-operative decongestive therapy

Intervention.evidence: randomly assigned to receive LVA with decongestive therapy or decongestive therapy alone

Objective.evidence: This multicentre randomised controlled trial assessed the efficacy of lymphatic venous anastomosis (LVA) in preventing cellulitis

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the frequency of cellulitis over a 6-month period

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a blocked random assignment with allocation concealment managed by the Clinical Trial Office

Blinding.evidence: Due to the nature of the interventions, blinding was not feasible

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 336 patients were randomised: 105 to the LVA group and 120 to the control group, between January 2017 and September 2019

Number_Analysed.evidence: In the full-analysis set, LVA with decongestive therapy significantly reduced cellulitis frequency

Harms.evidence: Four patients in the control group experienced contact dermatitis, which was mild and resolved with treatment
